 ABSTRACT The paper reviews recent reports on the level and growth of fuelwood consumption in Africa, and on the ecological, economic and possible micro-climatic effects of deforestation. It then reviews the economic and operational aspects of policies open to governments (i) to encourage fuelwood conservation, (ii) to facilitate the substitution of commercial energy for fuelwood, where desirable on grounds of relative costs, (iii) in developing the 'traditional' functions of the forestry services in maintaining the forest reserves and undertaking plantings in watersheds and shelterbelts, and (iv) in promoting the practice of agro-forestry, i.e. the planting and maintenance of trees in copses and around farms by the farm families themselves. All four are important, but it is argued that (iv) offers considerable promise in terms of increased planting rates, low budgetary requirements, ecological benefits and good economic and financial rates of return. The importance of the 'policy environment' for the success of each is also discussed, as are the various research, education, training and other requirements of (iv).  I OVERVIEW 1.1 This report first reviews recent studies 1/ on the growth of consumption of fuelwood in Africa, and on the economic, ecological and social consequences of deforestation. It then assesses the economic and operational merits of various policy options. Chapters II and III present the evidence and analysis in detail, while the present chapter provides a self-contained overview. It is found that there has been a convergence of views amongst foresters and economists in recent years on several practical steps that governments could take to begin to address the problem, given the commitment, and which by encouraging private as well as public plantings, conservation, and, depending on relative costs, a shift to 'commercial' fuels, would place modest demands on the governments' administrative and budgetary resources while offering prospects of very good economic returns to investment. Introduction: Fuelwood Consumption and Deforestation in Africa 1.2 In Africa around 90% of the population use fuelwood for cooking, in the equivalent amount of roughly 1.5 tons of oil per family per year. The consumption of fuelwood energy by households is typically ten times the total consumption of commercial energy for all purposes (including transport and electricity generation) in the low income countries, and in Nigeria twice the total. The annual rate of consumption has now reached the point where it is estimated to exceed the annual rate of additions to supply through the growth of trees by the following margins (estimates rounded): - in Senegal, by -35% (a slight surplus), - in the Sahelian countries, by 30%, - in Niger, by 200%, - in Northern Nigeria by 75%, - in Ethiopia, by 150%, - in Sudan, by 70%. 1.3 Forestry plantations and fuelwood plantings currently account for very small percentages (less than 5%) of supplies; fuelwood demands 1/ In particular the recent Energy Assessment and Forestry Sector Reports prepared by Bank staff and various publications listed in the bibliography. Furthermore the tree stocks are declining at an accelerating rate because consumption is increasing exponentially with population growth while the annual additions to supply through new tree growth (the mean annual increment) are declining in proportion to the volume of stocks. For this reason the excess of consumption over the mean annual increment is expected to rise to 620% in Niger by the end of the century, in the Sahelian countries together, to 130%, and in Northern Nigeria by around 250%. These estimates do not allow for the effects of land clearance for agricultural purposes, which in some regions contributes more to deforestation than fuelwood consumption, or for depletions in stocks arising from industrial consumption. The half-life of the tree stocks (the time which it would take for stocks to decline to half their current level) averages about 25 years in West African countries at present but, on account of the accelerating trends, is likely to average 10 years or less (on further depleted stocks) by the end of the century; very large areas have either experienced or soon face the prospects of very large losses of tree cover. 1.4 The rapid depletion of tree stocks is causing unprecedented- and, without remedial policies, irreversible - changes in the ecology of rural areas, principally in the carrying capacity or fertility of the soil. The depletion of tree stocks itself introduces a breach in the nutrient cycles in the affected areas, though this is perhaps less serious than the loss of protection they once provided against the erosion of the soil during rains and winds. But so long as demands for fuelwood continue to rise the nutrient cycles are breached in two further respects: in the removal of animal dung and of crop residues for fuel. Overgrazing and poor cropping practices further deplete the fertility of the soil. Originally, the ecological changes were confined to the Sahelian and Sahelo-Saharan belts, where low rainfalls and recurrent droughts make the land fragile, and exceedingly vulnerable to the economic activities of small populations. This is apparently why desertification advanced in the region over the centuries under the influence of, by today's measures, comparatively small perturbations associated with trans-Saharan trade, the establishment of small settlements, and the gum-arabic trade with Europe over the fifteenth to nineteenth centuries. 2/ However, the process of desertification associated with human economic activity is no longer confined to these areas. Professor Sharon Nicholson, in a report for the Club du Sahel, also concluded that "the possibility that human activities in the Sahel can affect its climate cannot be ruled out. On the contrary there is much evidence that landscape changes can act to reinforce the drought..." 2/ "Environmental Change in the West African Sahel", a study published in 1983 by the U.S. National Resarch Council.

It will be seen that their authors are careful to point to the uncertainties and ambiguities in the data, and in fact several make proposals for improving the data base on tree stocks and fuelwood consumption rates. Policy Options 1.6 Policy options fall into three categories: (i) substitution - principally of commercial fuels (kerosene, LPG, electricity) for fuelwood and charcoal in urban areas; (ii) conservation - through the encouragement of changes in people's methods and habits of cooking in ways that save fuelwood; and through increased efficiency in harvesting (reduction of wastes) and in charcoal conversion methods; (iii)increasing supplies - through investment in forestry and agro-forestry. 1.7 In regions of rising scarcity of fuelwood, all three changes are taking place autonomously under the influence of rising real costs cf fuelwood. Autonomous demand and supply adjustments, however, are appreciably less than what is required to address the problem in hand. Several reasons for this are discussed in Chapter III, but the most important one perhaps arises from people's open exploitation of forest reserves and wooded areas as a 'public' or 'free' good, without regard to the external environmental ard ecological costs noted above. This means that fuelwood demands are appreciably higher - i.e. economy in the use of fuelwood and the rate of substitution to 'commercial' fuels are both lower - and the supplies from new plantings are appreciably lower than is economically desirable. The theoretical answer to this problem is to apply a stumpage tax as an incentive for conservation, for substitution, and for private tree plantings, but the administrative and political difficulties of applying such a tax over large areas, and of protecting the forest reserves, are formidable, and in practice stumpage taxes amount to very small percentages of social. costs. Land tenure issues and the 'commons' problem are also thought to undermine the rate of investment in agro-forestry and fuelwood plantations. Nevertheless, the observed adjustments in demand and supply, working through the price mechanism, reveal an underlying responsiveness of the urbarn and rural populations to the changes now toking plece, and this provides a natural. starting point for the formulation of policies. (i) Substitution by Commercial Fuels 1.8 In a large number of African towns and cities, the real costs of cooking with fuelwood have risen above the real costs of cooking with
 - 4 - commercial fuels such as kerosene, LPG or, in some places, electricity. Hence in urban areas there is an economic gain from substitution, even ignoring the ecological benefits of reduced fuelwood consumption, and the price differences have in fact induced some substitution. However, only about 10% of Africa's population use commercial fuels for cooking, almost all in the urban areas, though this percentage may double or triple in the next 15 years with urbanization and growing fuelwood scarcity.- It is frequently repoted, also, that substitution does not take place extensively in urban areas until the surrounding tree stocks are badly depleted, often over a radius of a 50-100 miles or more. In rural-areas, the costs of distributing commercial fuels are very high, given the distances involved and the poor infrastructure. Hence the (private) cost differences between fuelwood and its commercial alternatives continue to favor the consumption of fuelwood or, once this runs out, crop residues and animal dung. 1.9 Hence the recommended policy is to encourage substitution and energy conservation in urban areas, including the regional towns and cities, while attempting to increase tree stocks and also encourage conservation in rural areas. Since policies with respect to the supply of commercial energy have been the subject of much analysis elsewhere - covering the pricing, investment and institutional aspects - no further comment is provided in this report. 3/ 1.10 The rate of substitution - and thus reductions in the rate of deforestation - will also depend on the oil importing countries' capacities to finance imports. The financing of energy imports in these countries absorbed small shares (around 10-15%) of export earnings in the 1960s, but now account for large and still growing shares, e.g. for 44% in Ethiopia in 1981, 63% in Kenya, 77% in Senegal, 44% in Sudan, 24% in Liberia and 23% in Niger. Hence the rate of substitution will depend crucially on the success with which the countries manage their trade and exchange rate policies. Indeed, the issue is wider than this, since the frequent overevaluation of currencies in African countries, and the preference for channeling resources away from agriculture (both exports and food crops) toward industry has greatly undermined the private returns to investment in rural areas, including, it must be concluded, investments in agro-forestry and erosion control. Hence for two reasons - the disincentives for the substitution of commercial fuels, and for investment in rural areas - the less successful the countries are in managing their trade and exchange rate policies, the greater will be the rate of deforestation. 3/ See e.g. the World Bank's recent report, The Energy Transition in Developing Countries (1983).

So far, however, programs to put the idea into practice have met with mixed success. As discussed in Chapter III, experiments suggested that two or three fold increases in the fuel efficiency of cooking would be possible over tradtional "three-stone" methods. In addition, the use of aluminum pots, whether on open fires or on stoves, has been found to add significantly to efficiency, with further gains being thought possible through improvements in cooking habits and utensils. Overall it was once thought that a four-fold reduction in the specific consumption rates of fuelwood could be achieved by these various devices, from around 0.8 cubic meters per capita per year, to 0.2 cubic meters. It is not difficult to show that such gains would greatly reduce the rate of deforestation. Furthermore, the costs are low; the stoves for instance can be made by artisans, with payback periods of 20-60 days assuming the efficiency gains are realized. 1.12 Undoubtedly one reason for the low response so far has been that the programs to effect such changes are still in their pilot phases, and were not intended to have a wide distribution; in this respect, it is still too early to arrive at definitive conclusions as to their success. It is thought however that the inefficiencies of traditional methods of cooking were over-estimated in tests, while, on the other hand, there is still much experimentation to be done to find stoves that meet with people's requirements. There have also been some difficulties with the ways the programs were organized. E.g. several attempts were made to implement the pregrams through the forestry services, which were not well placed to undertake the research or to disseminate the idea. It is now thought that it would be better to rely more on the private voluntary organizations, the rural extension services and the manufacturers themselves (most of whom are likely to be artisans and small scale establishments). 1.13 It shou].d be noted also that the costs of the programs are generally very small, being, e.g., only small fractions of one percent of, say, net public investments in energy. Hence financial support for the programs entails no significant financial risk for either donors or governments while offering prospects of large benefits if consumers and manufacturers respond to the idea. Hence the programs seem worth persisting with. (iii) Increasing Supplies by Replenishing Tree Stocks 1.14 There are broadly two complementary approaches: (a) Ihe "forestry approach", involving plantations, the better management of forest reserves, the recovery of forest residues, and the establishment of fuelwood and erosion control plantations in water-sheds and shelterbelts. This approach works through the forestry services;
 -6- (b) The "agro-forestry approach", involving the planting and maintenance of trees near dwellings, on the boundaries of arable land and in small lots (sometimes intercropped) by the farm families themselves. 1.15 The forestry approach has so far accounted for the larger share of government (and donor) allocations to fuelwood, ecology control and related investments in Africa. Rising scarcity prices frecuently show fuelwood plantations to have prospects of good financial and economic rates of returns, e.g. as with peri-urban plantations for towns and cities where local reserves are badly depleted, and multi-purpose plantations providing fuelwood, poles and erosion control in rural areas. The ecological benefits are also important, e.g. in watersheds and regions subject to loss of soil through winds, and may justify investments even where, on account of the public's open exploitation of existing reserves keeping prices down, the financial returns are low. 1.16 In terms of defining future policies, however, there is one over-riding issue associated with the forestry approach. This is that, institutionally and financially, what it can accomplish falls far short of what is needed to meet rural and urban demands for fuelwood and to protect the soil from erosion and losses in fertility in rural areas. For example, the World Bank's energy policy paper 4/ contained the results of some simulation studies by John Spears, from which it was concluded that, even if the demand for wood were to be reduced by 20 to 30 percent through conservation, and through subsititution for other fuels, a fifteenfold increase in current planting rates would be required in African countries to bring demand and supply into better balance by year 2000. These results were averages for quite large regions; in regions where fuelwood is most scarce, much larger increases in plarting rates were thought to be needed. Another way of looking at planting requirements is to note that plantations currently account for significantly less than 5% of fuelwood supplies, the balance of over 95% coming from the felling and lopping of natural woodland and farm fallow. 1.17 The budgetary institutional development problems to be surmounted to accomplish such an increase are formidable, and come at a time when forestry services in the region have received appreciable budget cuts rather than increases. While it is desirable for governments to increase budgetary allocations to the forestry services, increases of the order required to achieve a 15 fold increase or more in the planting rates and, equally important, to maintain the plantations and existing forest reserves, do not seem a realistic proposition. In addition there would be the difficulties of recruiting, training and managing very large increases in the forestry labor force. 4/ "The Energy Transition in Developing Countries", 1983.

Agro-forestry practices 5/ are sometimes described as 'old traditions in the Soudano-Sahelian zones of West Africa, though it is now believed that they are breaking down under the influences of the growth of human and animal populations, the demand for fuelwood, and changes in cropping practices in the region. So far, however, there has been little government support for the development of the practices, and it. is reported that much of the land clearing taking place for agricultural development proiects has further discouraged their development., Yet of the policies so far put forward, those for rekindling and developing the traditions further offer the most grounds for encouragement: (i) Planting Rates. Farmers outnumber foresters by 1,000 to 10,000 to 1. If their families spend, say, only 10 days per year on the planting and care of trees, as an "off-farm" activity, their combined labor inputs would outweigh that of the foresters by 40 to 400 to 1. If then the farmers arc given adequate incentives to adopt the practice, with suitable encouragement and advice from the rural extension services, and are supplied with seedlings, an appreciable increase in planting rates would be achievable; (ii) Costs and Returns. The financial costs of wage labor, which are the main expenditure item in the forestry services' budgets, would be eliminated (though further investments in extension would be needed). The economic costs of farm families' labor would also be reduced, over the long-term, because of the time that would otherwise have to be spent in gathering and transporting fuelwood, and the possibility arises that the social costs of the programs would be negative, i.e. there would be a social gain. These factors make the practice of agro-forestry financially and economically attractive. The economic and financial attractiveness is further increased by: (iii)Ecological Benefits. These are revealed most directly in the crop yields. Agro-forestry practices require dispersed plantings of large numbers of trees over large areas, as compared to the concentrated plantings over relatively small areas of the forestry appraoch. This means that the ecological benefits of improved nutrient cycles, improved moisture retention in the soil and reduced soil erosion are both larger and better distributed over the farm lands. It also means that there would be positive financial returns to the farmers; 5/ For further details on the practices, see Agro-forestry in the West African Sahel, National Academy Press, Washington, D.C., 1983.

For Northern Nigeria it is estimated that 40-50 trees planted on farm boundaries and near dwellings, occupying less than 5% of arable land on, say, a 2 hectare farm is sufficient to meet the fuelwood needs of a farm family. One reason for this is that the yields of free-standing trees are typically 3 or more times those in plantations and forests. In more arid northern Soudanian and Sahelian regions yields are significantly lower, so correspondingly more plantings over a greater proportion of arable area would be needed if self-sufficiency in fuelwood were sought; nevertheless, and even where self-sufficiency is not sought, the practice would make a significant contribution to fuelwood supplies, providing by-products such as fruit, fodder and shade, reducing erosion, and improving the carrying capacity of the soil. (v) Farmer Response. The low costs, the ecological benefits, and the prospects of good economic and financial returns, provide reasons for expecting a good response to the agro-forestry approach, as has been the experience with social forestry projects in India (see Part III). 1.19 In practice, the main factor working against the development of agro-forestry is the externality problem noted earlier, which is that, so long as local tree stocks are not in short supply and can be cut as a 'free good,' there is little incentive for private plantings. Further, the ecological costs of overcutting are indirect and delayed, and not immediately apparent. In these circumstances, there is a good case for programs to encourage the practice, e.g. through the extension services, supporting research into suitable species of trees, and through the establishment of networks of nurseries (see para 1.21 below and Part III). 1.20 The unit costs of such programs to support agro-forestry are also very low - of the order of 10% to 20% of the costs of plantation projects, possibly less. The changing emphasis in the arid and semi-arid zones of West Africa to tree planting more closely associated with, and carried out by private house-owners and farmers, would require fundamental changes in the priorities of fcrestry research, university curricula and technician training. Research and extension linkages in forestry scarcely exist today in the majority of the West African countries. It is noteworthy also that forestry is never included in T and V agricultural extension programs. In the forthcoming era of integrated tree-planting with farming it will be vital to invest further in the education of extension workers as to the practices of agro-forestrv and to provide supporting research. The forestry research centers,which have suffered from much neglect in African countries, thus merit far more budgetary and developmental support than they have received in the past. In addition to providing a source of seedlings themselves, public and community nurseries could serve a valuable demonstration effect for private investments.
 - 10 - Summary 1.22 Several studies in recent years have converged towards operationally workable policies for addressing the problems stemming from the consumption of fuelwood in Africa. It is desirable to persist, in the first place, with programs to encourage savings on fuelwood consumption and, in the second, with addressing the various issues affecting the supply of commercial energy and thus (especially in urban areas) its substitution for the burning of fuelwood and charcoal. Third, it is economically desirable to increase budgetary and developmental support for the traditional work of the forestry services, particularly in the management of the forest reserves and the establishment of erosion control plantations in water-sheds and shelterbelts; plantations for fuelwood and its by-products, if appropriately located, also can show good rates of return. Each have their contribution to make and the appropriate circumstances for investment, at least for commercial fuels and forestry projects, should be revealed by economic and financial analysis. It would be desirable, however, to take further the current (and somewhat small and isolated initiatives) to develop agro-forestry practices in Africa. In terms of its prospective economic and ecological benefits, financially low risks, and breadth of scope, the development of agro-forestry would merit substantially increased support from Governments and development agencies.

(These practices are known under several names, e.g. as social forestry, rural forestry, agro-sylvo-pastoral associations, or agro-forestry, the last of these terms being preferred in this paper.) An overview of the policy options associated with each was provided in Chapter I. The present Chapter presents the same arguments, but in more detail, drawing on several reports by Bank staff and others. Some Limitations of 'Autonomous' Demand and Supply Responses 3.2 Under the influence of rising real costs of fuelwood, both absolutely and relative to the costs of substitutes, all four of the above adjustments are reported to be taking place, notwithstanding negligibly low levels of government intervention. This has led some economists to wonder if reforestation and agro-forestry investments are not best 'left to the market' so to speak, given a proper management of a country's price mechanism. 3.3 There are, however, reasons for thinking that such 'autonomous' demand and supply responses are less than what is economically desirable. Commonly cited are the low levels of monetization of rural economic activities and an associated under-development of capital and insurance markets to support term-investments in trees (as in agriculture); the (large) fixed or indivisible costs of establishing infrastructural and marketing services in rural areas; uncertainities in the yields (or mean annual increment) arising from changing soil conditions and the great variability of rainfalls between locations in any year, between years, and even between decades (see paras 3.23 to 3.27 below); and the point that the ecological costs of overcutting are delayed and indirect, such that the 'autonomous' response itself is delayed too long (and is often too late). Hence a priority for the forestry and energy departments much be the establishment of a proper information base for planning purposes, and a svstem for monitoring the changes taking place. A related need for project design is for sociological surveys into questions of ownership rights, of land and of trees, since traditional tenure systems "may prevail and, at times, run counter to formal legislation." 26/ Surveys are also necessary for a proper understanding of demand. Available surveys have found that farmers plant trees for several purposes, besides fuelwood and erosion control, such as for fruit, fodder, building poles and shade, and are more likely to be responsive to programs if the nurseries, public or private, can ensure a ready supply of trees suited to their purposes. 3.48 The information base for research into, and the monitoring of, climate and the changing ecology of Africa leaves much to be desired, and has been a source of concern among scientists. Analyses of climate and ecology go together becaue of feedback between the two: the effects of climate on soil fertility and, less understood, the micro-climatic effects of changes in the vegetative cover the moisture content of the 26/ AGR Technical Note No. 3, "Sociological Aspects of Forestry Project Design" by Noronha, 1980.

As noted earlier, Professor Nicholson has drawn attention to a serious deterioration of observation and data transmission networks for surface and upper air measurementsin the Sahelian region, while the ecological changes taking place are poorly monitored - when they are monitored at all. 3.49 Research, Training and Education The changing emphasis in the arid and semi-arid zones of West Africa to tree planting vore closely associated with, and carried out by private house-owners and farmers, requires fundamental changes in the priorities of forestry research, university curricula and technician training. Research and extension linkages in forestry scarcely exist today in the majority of the West African countries. It is noteworthy also that forestry is never included in T and V agricultural extension programs. A successful blending will be necessary to resolve the increasingly severe fuelwood supply problems facing many communities i Africa. 3.50 Research. A recent Bank paper on desertification in West Africa has made the following points: 27/ (a) existing national research centres should be utilized and strengthened. This coud be helped by "twinning" institutions in developed countries with national research centres in the developing countries. (b) there are good reasons for establishing a regional center in West Africa to specialize in agro-sylvo-pastotal resarch, or at least to coordinate it. A start to this proposal would be to collect all the information available on past research efforts in this region. (c) Technologies. Although tree-planting, usually with exotics, has been sucessfully carried out in West Africa since the beginning of the 20th century, success has been due largely to the fact that the plantations were sited on superior sites during a period when the rainfall in general was above average and adequate for good tree growth. The current drought, and dearth of good soils now available for tree-planting, have created a situation in which it is unlikely that large blocks of plantations now have any place in resolving the fuelwood crisis. Nevertheless, improved technical packages are required, and the individual survivors of the drought - both exotic and indigenous multi-purpose species - should be utilized for bio-technology advances. The most important advances are likely to come from the following: 27/ By Mr. Gorse.

Rooted cuttings and tissue culture are the techniques that need to be utilized; inoculation of the trees with symbiotic micro-organisms which enable the tree roots to fix atmospheric nitrogen, improve the supply of phosphorous to the plant, enhance the uptake of trace elements and increase the absorption of soil moisture; intercropping food production with suitable trees and shrubs, utilizing the technique involving symbiotic micro-organisms to maintain soil fertility; and evaluation and improvement of tree and shrub fodder species for the important dry season protein feed to livestock. (d) Donor coordination. A missing link in forestry (as in agricultural) research is the schism between basic research at the university level, field trials by research centers and adoption by the farmers. Part of the trouble arises from the universities and research centers competing for funds available from different sources. There is obviously much that donors might do to help by coordinating their assistance for the development of national centers, and also for the developmert of the agro-sylvo-pastoral center proposed above. 3.50 Training and education. West African university forestry education has been dominated by curricula derived from developed forestry cultures. It should be possible by now however for local institutes to develop curricula more suited to the local environment and problems. (iii) Extension services and Agro-forestry 3.51 The T and V extension programs need to include forestry for the farmers. This need not be at a sophisticated level. The majority of the tree and shrub species likely to be useful are robust and not difficult to raise from seed and plant out. The intrinsic value of the trees and shrubs to the well-being of the farmers, and the importance of early protection until well established are perhaps the most important elements in such an extension program. Training of the extension workers therefore needs to concentrate on these aspects. 3.52 The involvement of the rural extension services, as opposed to extension services provided by the forestry departments, would be something of a departure from previous practices. But it offers considerable scope both for cost reducticns and for better relating farm-tree planting activities to agricultural and pastoral activities in a way that will enhance farm output. On the cost side Mr. Hvidberg-Hansen has expressed the idea succinctly as follows, in
 - 47 - connection with the preparatory work on a project in Nigeria: 28/ "A major effort should be initiated to involve the farmers in the program, primarily through the extension services. Rather than duplicating at considerable cost the existing agricultural extension services in the five participating states, the program should develop training materials, data and practical information for use by existing agricultural extension workers in a continued agriculture and tree planting conservation/extension effort. More specifically, this would involve close working agreements with current statewide ADPs (Agricultural development projects) and forthcoming new State ADPs, to establish a fcrum for joint training design and the training of trainers and extension workers." 3.53 Experience from other regions supports this conclusion of working with or through existing agricultural extension services, rather than requiring forestry departments to undertake the work entirely themselves. The social forestry projects in India have taken this approach, with considerable success both in terms of lowering costs and achieving a widespread response from rural families. 29/ 3.54 Obviously, it is necessary for the extension services to be supported by, and to be kept abreast of, developments in agro-forestry research. Past experience has clearly shown that farmers will not adopt new technologies that put their precarious food production systems at risk, or that do not offer immediate economic advantages. The same attitudes will face the introduction of new forestry technologies. (iv) Nurseries, Seedling Distribution and Planting Techniques 30/ 3.55 A key to fostering 'spontaneous' tree planting efforts, and to accelerating the planting rates, is the establishment of effective distribution systems for tree nurseries. Again, this requires changes in the policies of forestry departments. Historically, the departments have favored centralized large scale nurseries producing trees in polythene pots. By contrast, for rural tree planting to be effective, a decentralized tree nursery network is essential. In one Indian State where social forestry is being promoted, the density of nurseries has been increased from 1 per 83 villages in 1980 to 1 to every 10 villages in 1983. Traditionally polythene potted stock costs something ir the order of $50 or mere per 1000 trees. Each tree has a ball of soil around the roots and the tree plus polythene pot weighs about a kilo. It is difficult for a farmer to carrry more than 10 such trees at a time from a nursery back to the farm homestead, and the distance to be walked from the nursery to the homestead becomes critical.. In order to overcome this, new low cost techniques have been devised and are being successfully applied in many countries. Notable is the "basket" system in which several hundred small seedlings are raised in a shallow straw basket and grown to about 1 inch in height. Such a basket of trees can be carried as a head load or on a bicycle back to the village and distributed to a farmer's neighbors. 3.57 Another highly effective system is direct seeding. Under a '10 cent Tree Seed Packet Scheme' introduced in Kenya in the 1950s, large numbers of farmers in the Kericho and Nyanza region planted Eucalyptus and Black Wattle seed on their holdings for a very low cost. Direct seeding of hedge species is practiced in some African countries, and merits expansion. Few forest services have an organized tree seed distribution system for the rural areas. Several thousand kilometers of strip plantations have been seeded in India in recent years, and direct seeding is commonly practiced in China. The costs are extremely low (less than $5/1000 trees, less than one tenth of planting 'potted stock', ignoring savings in distribution costs).

doc.repnme: Fuelwood consumption and deforestation in African countries
doc.abstracts: The paper reviews recent reports on the level and growth of fuelwood consumption in Africa, and on the ecological, economic and possible micro-climatic effects of deforestation. It then reviews the economic and operational aspects of policies open to governments: (i) to encourage fuelwood conservation; (ii) to facilitate the substitution of commercial energy for fuelwood, where desirable on grounds of relative costs; (iii) in developing the "traditional" functions of the forestry services in maintaining the forest reserves and undertaking plantings in watersheds and shelterbelts; and (iv) in promoting the practice of agro-forestry, i.e. the planting and maintenance of trees in copses and around farms by the farm families themselves. All four are important, but it is argued that (iv) offers considerable promise in terms of increased planting rates, low budgetary requirements, ecological benefits and good economic and financial rates of return. The importance of the "policy environment" for the success of each is also discussed, as are the various research, education, training and other requirements of (iv).
